sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Pinfold.
sp.p: Sir, I have answered you already, that upon my own Knowledge I cannot say it is his Hand-writing; but because I have heard of such a Paper, I do believe it may be his.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Iust.
sp.p: Did you ever see my Lord Bishop write?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Pinfold.
sp.p: I have been in his Chamber several times when he has been Writing, but I had more Manners than to look upon what he Writ.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Iust.
sp.p: Did you never see him write his Name?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Pinfold.
sp.p: I do not know that I ever saw him write his Name, but I have seen him Writing I say, and so my Lord Bishop may have seen me Writing; but I believe he does not know my Hand.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: You have seen him write you say.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Pinfold.
sp.p: I tell you Mr. Sollicitor, I have been in his Chamber when he has been Writing, but I had more Manners than to look over him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iust. Powel.
sp.p: Then you did never see any of that Writing.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Pinfold.
sp.p: I cannot say I did, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray did you never see any of his Writing but that Letter you speak of.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Pinfold.
sp.p: No, not that I remember.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iust. Powel.
sp.p: Mr. Sollicitor, you must call other Witnesses, for this does not prove any thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: We will go on—Swear Mr. Clavel.

div.p: Mr. Clavel Sworn.

sp.speaker: Mr Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Do you know my Lord Bishop of Peterburgh's Hand-writing or no?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavel.
sp.p: I have seen it many times.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Do you know it when you see it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavel.
sp.p: I believe I do, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray look upon that Paper, and upon your Oath tell us, do you believe that Name to be his Writing, or no?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavel.
sp.p: I do believe it is, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray look upon the rest of the Hands there, do you know any of the other Names?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavel.
sp.p: No, I do not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Have you ever seen any of their Writing?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavell.
sp.p: It is probable I may have seen some, but do not now remember it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: I think you are a Bookseller, Mr. Clavell.

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavell.
sp.p: Yes, I am so, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: I suppose you have had some Dealings with them in the way of your Trade, Did you never see any of their Writing?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavell.
sp.p: I have seen the Names of some of them; but it is so long since that I cannot Remember.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Did you ever see my Lord of Peterborough Write?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavell.
sp.p: I cannot tell whether ever I saw him Write his Name or no; but I have had several Letters from my Lord of Peterborough.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Is that his Hand-writing?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavell.
sp.p: I cannot say it is, I believe it is.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: You have had Letters from him you say?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavell.
sp.p: Yes, and it seems to be like his Hand.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pollixfen.
sp.p: But you never saw him Write his Hand you say?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavell.
sp.p: I cannot say I ever did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: These Letters that you have received from my Lord of Peterborough, did he own them? Do you think they were Counterfeit, or of his own Hand-writing?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavell.
sp.p: I suppose he has owned them, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. I. Powell.
sp.p: But you must Answer directly, Sir, Did he own them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What did those Letters concern? were they about Books, or what?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavell.
sp.p: They were sometimes about one business, sometimes about another.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Was the subject-matter of any of these Letters about Mony; and was it paid you? Did you receive, or did you give any account of it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavell.
sp.p: They were about several Businesses.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Look you, Mr. Clavell, you must give us as particular account as you can.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, upon those Letters were the things done that those Letters required.

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavell.
sp.p: Yes▪ they were.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did you do your part?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavell.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Now I would ask you, Do you believe that Name of my Lord Bishop of Peterborough to be the Hand-writing of my Lord Bishop?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavell.
sp.p: I believe it is.

sp.speaker: Mr. I. Powell.
sp.p: Do you know that those Letters that you say you received from my Lord, were of my Lords own Hand-writing, Do you Swear that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavell.
sp.p: My Lord I cannot Swear that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Finch.
sp.p: Do you know whether the Letters, that you received, as you say, were written by my Lord himself, or by his Secretary?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavell.
sp.p: I have received Letters from him, and his Secretary too.

sp.speaker: Sir G. Treby.
sp.p: But were you present with him when he writ any Letters with his own Hand?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: You do not mean a Letter to your self sure, Sir George?

sp.speaker: Sir G. Treby.
sp.p: No Sir, I say any Letters.

sp.speaker: Mr. Clavell.
sp.p: I have been present with my Lord often, but I cannot say I have seen my Lord write.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: He has here told you, he has had several Letters of my Lords own Hand, and from his Secretary too.

sp.speaker: Mr. I. Powell.
sp.p: He has said it, but you see he says he never saw him write.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: We have given Evidence against my Lord Arch-Bishop, Lord Bishop of Ely, St. Asaph, Peterborough, and Bristol.

sp.speaker: Mr. I. Powell.
sp.p: Certainly Mr. Sollicitor you mistake—But go on—

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: We have given Evidence I say against them, Sir, but whether it be sufficient Evidence, we shall Argue by and by.—Call Mr. Hooper and Mr. Chetwood again.

div.p: Mr. Chetwood appeared.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Do you know the Hand-writing of my Lord Bishop of Bath and Wells?

sp.speaker: Mr. Chetwood.
sp.p: I have seen it Twice or Thrice, but it is a considerable time since I did see it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Do you believe that is his Hand-writing?

sp.speaker: Mr. Chetwood.
sp.p: I never saw him writ •… his Name in my Life.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray look upon the Name, and tell us what you believe of it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Chetwood.
sp.p: I believe it may, but I do not certainly know it to be his Hand, I rather believe it is my Lord Bishop of Bath and Wells his Hand, than I believe that other to be my Lord of Peterboroughs.

sp.speaker: Sir G. Treby.
sp.p: Do you believe that to be my Lord of Peterborough's Hand or no?

sp.speaker: Mr. Chetwood.
sp.p: I say, I rather believe that this is the Bishop of Bath and Wells his Writing, than that which is above it or below it, to be their Writing; but truly I do not distinctly know my Lord Bishop of Bath and Wells his Hand.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Call Mr. Hooper.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: You are very lame in this matter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: The Witnesses are unwilling, and we must find out the Truth as well as we can.

div.p: Mr. Hooper did not appear.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Call Mr. Iames and Mr. Powell.

div.p: Mr. James appeared and was Sworn.

sp.speaker: Mr Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Do you know my Lord Bishop of Bristol's Writing, Mr. Iames?

sp.speaker: Mr. Iames.
sp.p: Yes, I believe I do, but I am not so certain, because my Lord Writes several times several Hands.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Shew him the Paper: Is that my Lord of Bristol's Hand?

sp.speaker: Mr. Iames.
sp.p: I cannot say it is or no.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What do you believe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Iames.
sp.p: It looks like his Hand, and that's all I can say.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: But pray hearken, and Answer to what I ask you; you are prepared for one Question it may be, and I shall ask you another: upon your Oath, Do you believe it to be the Hand-writing of my Lord of Bristol?

sp.speaker: Mr. Iames.
sp.p: Upon my Oath, I can only say it looks like it, that's all.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Did you ever see him Write?

sp.speaker: Mr. Iames.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I have seen his Hand-writing several times, and it is like his Hand-writing, that is all I can say.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Sir, remember you are upon your Oath, and Answer my Question.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iames.
sp.p: Upon my Oath, I know no more than that, Sir William Williams.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: I ask you, Sir, whether you believe it to be his Hand or not?

sp.speaker: Mr. Iames.
sp.p: My Lord, it looks like his Hand, and it may be his Hand.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: But you do think and believe one way or other: What do you believe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Iames.
sp.p: It may be his Hand, for what I know, and it may not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: It may be your Hand.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iames.
sp.p: No, Sir, it cannot be mine, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What do you believe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Iames.
sp.p: I believe it may be his Hand, or it may not be his Hand, that is all I can say.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Come, Sir, you must Answer fairly, Do you believe it to be his Hand, or do you not?

sp.speaker: Mr. Iames.
sp.p: Yes, I do believe it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: You are very hard to believe methinks.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iames.
sp.p: No, I am not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: You do very well now Mr. Iames; when you do well, we'll commend you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Call Mr. Nathaniel Powell.

div.p: Mr. Powell was Sworn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let's know what's your Name.

sp.speaker: Mr. Powell.
sp.p: My Name is Nathaniel Powell.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray do you know the Hand-writing of my Lord Bishop of Chichester.

sp.speaker: Mr. Powell.
sp.p: I have not seen the Paper, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Do you know his Hand-writing?

sp.speaker: Mr. Powell.
sp.p: Yes, I believe I do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Look upon that Name of his.

sp.speaker: Mr. Powell.
sp.p: I did not see my Lord Write that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Who says you did: no Body asks that of you; how you Answer! Pray Sir, remember your Oath, and Answer seriously, Do you believe it to be his Writing or no?

sp.speaker: Mr. Powell.
sp.p: I believe it is like my Lord's Hand-writing, but I did never see him Write it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: No Body says you did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Powell.
sp.p: Therefore I cannot Swear positively it is his Hand.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: We do not ask that neither.

sp.speaker: Mr. Powell.
sp.p: I cannot tell whether it be his Hand or no.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Sir, you must Answer the Question directly, and seriously: Do you believe it, or do you not believe it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Powell.
sp.p: I cannot tell what to believe in the Case.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Then I ask you another Question, upon your Oath, Do you believe it is not his Hand?

sp.speaker: Mr. Powell.
sp.p: I cannot say that neither.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Once again, I ask you, upon your Oath, Do you believe it to be his Hand? I ask you plainly, and let Mankind Judge of you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Powell.
sp.p: I tell you, Sir, I cannot tell what to believe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, if these things be endured, there will be an end of all Testimony, if Witnesses do not answer fairly to the Questions that are asked them.

sp.speaker: Mr. I. Powell.
sp.p: Truly to me, for a Man to Swear his Belief in such a matter, is an extraordinary thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: He is obliged to answer Questions, when they are fairely put to him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pollixfen.
sp.p: I think that is a hard Question, not to be Answered.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Make your Exceptions to the Evidence if you please.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: First, he says, He knows his Hand; then he says, He has seen him write; and then he says, He did not see him write this; but he shuffles, he won't answer whether he believes it or not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pollixfen.
sp.p: The Question is, Whether belief in any case be Evidence?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: If they have a mind to a Bill of Exceptions upon that point, let them Seal their Bill, and we'll Argue it with them when they will; in the mean time, we'll go on, and that which we now pray, my Lord, is, That this Paper may be Read.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We have given sufficient Evidence sure to have it Read, therefore we desire it may be Read.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Levinz.
sp.p: My Lord, before this Paper be Read, we hope you will let us be heard to it: we think that what they desire (to have this Paper Read) ought not to be: for what is all the proof that they have given of this Paper? they have a proof by Comparison of Hands, which in a Criminal Case ought not to be received: and besides, my Lord, what is that Comparison of Hands, that they have offered? Some persons come here and say, They cannot tell whether it be their Hands, they believe it may or it may not, for ought they know; How shall we Convict any Man upon such a Testimony as this? can we have our Remedy against him for Perjury, for saying, He believes it to be our Hand? therefore here is not any Evidence to Charge us. For first, It is only a Comparison of Hands; And secondly, That Comparison is proved in such an uncertain manner: Some of them tell you, They do not know what to believe; another tells you, I believe 'tis rather such a Lord's Hand; then the others are such a Lord's Hands, I believe 'tis rather his Hand than that above it, or that below it; what sort of proof is all this? Therefore we pray it may not be Read till they prove it better.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Pamberton.
sp.p:
Pray, my Lord, spare me a word or two in this matter for Evidence sake, there is a great deal of reason we should take Exceptions to the Evidence that has been given: for truly I think I never heard such a sort of Evidence given before; It is a Case of as great Concernment as ever was in Westminster •… all; and for them to come to prove Hands only by those that saw Letters, but never saw the persons Write; this I hope will not amount to so much as a Comparison of Hands. Your Lordship knows, that in every petty Cause, where it depends upon the Comparison of Hands, they use to bring some of the Parties Hand writing, which may be Sworn to, to be the Parties own Hand, and then it is to be compared in Court with what is endeavoured to be proved, and upon comparing them together in Court, the Jury may look upon it, and see if it be right; and never was there any such a thing as this admitted in any poor petty Cause, that is but of the value of Forty Shillings. And therefore as to this Evidence, First, We say Comparison of Hands ought not to be given at all in the Cases of Criminals; And I believe it was never heard of that it should. In the next place, if it be admitted to be Evidence, yet it is not such an Evidence, as that by Comparison of Hands the Jury can take notice of it; for in such
manner of proofs by Comparison of Hands, the usage is, That the Witness is first asked, concerning the Writing he produces, Did you see this Writ by the Defendant, whose Hand they would prove? If he answers yes, I did, then should the Jury upon Comparison of what the Witness Swears to, with the Paper that is to be proved, judge whether those Hands be so like as to induce them to believe, that the sames person Writ both; and not that the Witness should say, I had a Letter from such a person, and this is like the Hand of that Letter, therefore I believe it to be his Hand: My Lord, I hope this shall never be admitted for Evidence in this Court.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: I do take it, that the Witness himself is Judge of the Comparison; for if he does know the Parties Hand, and a Paper be offered him to prove the Parties Hand, he is to compare it in his own mind.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Pemberton.
sp.p: It never was admitted to be so, that I know of, my Lord, or ever Read of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: You may remember several Cases about that, particularly Sidney's Case.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pollixfen.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, hear me a little as to that: it is a Point of very great moment, whether in the Case of a Misdemeanour either in an Indictment or Information, it be good Evidence to offer Comparison of Hands; and that this Court did adjudge quite contrary upon an Indictment of Forgery against my Lady Carr, appears in Syderfin's Reports; they went to prove her Letters Written by her to Cox, the Court rejected it, and gave their judgement here, That it was no Evidence; and that for this Reason, Because of the evil consequences of it. For said they, It is an easie matter for any Man's Hand to be Counterfeited; that they sure will agree, for frequent daily experience shews how easily that may be done: is it not easie then to cut any Man down in the World, by proving it is like his Hand? and proving that likenss by comparing it with something that he hath formerly seen? this strikes mighty deep; the honestest Man in the World and the most Innocent may be destroyed, and yet no fault to be found in the Jury or in the Judges; if the Law were so, it would be an unreasonable Law. Next, my Lord, for the Case of Sidney, that was a Case of Treason. Now in the Case of Treason there is always other Evidence brought; and this Evidence comes in, but as a Collateral Evidence, to strengthen the other; but in this Case it is the single Evidence, for ought that appears, for there is nothing more (for ought I can see) in the Case, but whether this were their Hands, and proved only by what another believes: Now shall any be condemned by anothers belief without proof? surely, my Lord, that was never Evidence yet to Convict any one; so that their proof failes in both Points; For first, It ought to be considered whether Comparison of Hands be Evidence in a Case of Misdemeanour; And next if it be Evidence, whether you will take it, that the belief of a Man that brings nothing to compare with it, or never saw the Party Write, but has received Letters, and says, This is like it, and therefore he believes it to be his Hand, be good Evidence as a Comparison of Hands.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Pemberton.
sp.p: My Lord, they are pleased to mention—

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Serj. you have been heard already, and you are not to reply upon us; or if you would, we must be heard first.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Pemberton.
sp.p: I would only speak to that Case of Sidney: my Lord, that Case differs from this toto Caelo, the Writing was found in his possession, in his Study; there was the proof that nailed him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: You shall see how we'll apply it by and by.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p:
Pray, my Lord, favour me a word in this matter: that there is stronger and weaker Evidence no Man doubts; but that which these Gentlemen say, that in this Case there is no Evidence, must needs be a mistake: if they mean, that it is not so strong an Evidence as is possible to be given, I agree with them, it is not: For if we had brought three or four Men that had seen them Write this very Paper, and put their Names to it, that had been a stronger Evidence than this, that we have given; but whether we do not give such a sort of Evidence as may induce the Jury to belive, that this is their Paper, and their Hands to it, we submit: they say, This is such a method as never was taken; but I admire that that should be said by Men of their Experience and Knowledge in the Law; for is there any thing more usual, or any other course taken for the proof of Hands, than for a Wittness to say, He knows the Hand of the Party very well, for he has often seen his Hand-writing, or received Lettters from him? and if you shew him the thing that you would prove to be his Hand, and he says,
I do believe this to be his Hand, for this Reason, Because I have had other things of his Writing: Certainly in the Experience of any Man that has practised, this is an Evidence that is given every day, and allowed for Evidence. For the Case of Mr. Sidney, which your Lordship has heard mentioned, it is certainly very opposite to this purpose; it is insisted upon and pretended. That that was Evidence, because it was found in his Study: but without all doubt, that would not be the reason: for may not a Book of another Man's Writing be found in my Study? and he insisted upon it in his own Defence: but the Answer was, That it should be left as the Question, Whether the Jury would believe it upon the Evidence that was given, of its being his own Hand-writing: And so in this Case, though it be not so strong Evidence, as if we had brought those that had seen them Write it; yet Evidence it is, and whether it be sufficient to satisfie the Jury, may be a Question; but no Question, it is good Evidence in Law.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: It is a wonderful thing, they say, That such Evidence should be offered: but truly, my Lord, it is a much stranger thing to hear Mr. Serj. Pemberton say, It was never done before; and then to make that Remark to your Lordship upon the Case of Sidney, which I'le put to your Lordship and the Court as a Case, and let him contradict me if he can; and then we shall see how far it goes. Sidney was Indicted for High Treason; and the Treason insisted upon was, A Writing supposed to be his, it being found in his Study; the Question was, Whether it was his Hand-writing or no? there was no positive Evidence that is was his Hand-writing; there was no Evidence produced that proved it to be his Hand-writing; for there was no one that Swore, That they they saw him Write it; there was nothing proved, but the similitude of Hands. Ay, but says Mr. Serj. Pemberton, It was found in his Study: will Mr. Serj. Pemberton be content, that all the Libels that are found in his Study, shall, for that reason, be adjudged to be Libels, to be his Hand-writing, and he to be a Libeller for them? I think he will make a severe Declamation against that, and he would have very good reason for it: Certainly that which was Evidence in one Man's Case, will be Evidence in another. God forbid there should be any such distinction in Law; and therefore I conclude that this is good Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Pemberton.
sp.p: The Court went upon this. That it was found in his Study, and compared with Letters and Bills of Exchange produced in Court; which were Sworn to be of his Hand-writing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p:
My Lord, I was by all the time; for I was ordered to attend him in the Tower; and therefore I can tell what passed as well as any Body. My Lord, they proved no more as to that Libel, but only by Comparison of Hands; they had no other proof in that Case, but by comparing the Hand-writing; and that was insisted upon to be a mighty fallible thing: That which they would have for us to compare, Paper with Paper, it is true, would make the proof somewhat stronger, if we could, in such a Case as this, be able to produce such Evidence: but I appeal to your Lordship, and shall leave it to the Jury, to consider which is better Evidence; these Men, that have been produced, that have been Conversant with these Lords, and acquainted with their Hand-writing, and who (as your Lordship sees) are not willing Men to give Evidence, they avoid it as much as they can; and they Swear it all to be the Hand-writing of the Archbishop of Canterbury, as they believe; which is as far as any Man can Swear. One says the whole Body of the Paper is my Lord of Canterbury's Hand, and he knows it very well; so that we are not upon a single Name, but a whole Paper that contains many Lines; and this is as much as can be proved by any one, that did not see the thing Written. Then, my Lord, for the rest of the Company, the Evidence is not so strong against every one of them, as it is against my Lord Archbishop; but is strong enough certainly to Convict them of what we accuse them of: and pray, my Lord, what was the Objection in Sidney's Case, but what has been mentioned here? That any Man's Hand might be Counterfeited. I remember in that Case, there was one Mr. Wharton, a young Gentleman, then in the Court, that undertook to the Court, That he would Counterfeit
that Hand presently; and he that was to Swear the Comparison, should not know, which was the one, and which was the other; which certainly was a stronger Case than this. And I see some of the Learned Gentlemen that are now standing at the Bar, who pressed this matter very hard against Mr. Sidney, and Mr. Sidney lost his Life upon that Comparison of Hands; though Mr. Wharton did Testifie how easie a matter it was to have a Man's Hand Counterfeited; and we all know was a Man of Value and Quality; so there is a President for Mr. Serj. Pemberton, that never heard of this Law before. They say the proving of similitude of Hands is no Evidence, unless you prove the actual Writing; what a condition then will England be in, when Witnesses are Dead? Is it not the most common practice that can be, to produce Witnesses to prove such Men are Dead, whose Names are set as Witnesses to Deeds; and they Swear, They believe it to be the Hand-Writing of those Witnesses? Can there be any greater Evidence of such a Case, unless it be the confession of the Party himself? My Lord, we are now only upon reading this Paper. We have been heard, and they have been heard; now we pray the Paper may be Read.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: We pray it may be Read.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Levinz.
sp.p: If your Lordship please—

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: We are not to be replied upon, Mr. Serjeant.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: You have spoke Brother Levinz, and you have spoke Brother Pemberton, and I would willingly hear you what you have to say; but we must not have vying and revying, for then we shall have no end.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Levinz.
sp.p: I would offer your Lordship some new matter which has not been touched upon yet; why it is not to be Read.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: What's that Brother?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Levinz.
sp.p: All the proof that has been given whatsoever it amounts to has been only of its being Written, but no proof has been given of its being Written in the County of Middlesex, where the Information is laid, and the matter is Local.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: First Read it, and then make your Objection.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: My Lord, as to the Evidence that has been given, I would only put your Lordship in mind of one Case; and that was the Case of Sir Samuel Barnardiston: and the great Evidence there, was the proof of its being his Hand-writing; and that being proved, was sufficient to Convict him of a Libel: for they could not believe Sir Samuel Barnardiston was Guilty of making Libels, unless they were proved to be his Hand-writing.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert Sawyer.
sp.p: He owned them to be his Hand-writing.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: If you do expect my Opinion in it, whether this be good Evidence, and whether this Paper be proved or no; I am ready to give it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Finch.
sp.p: My Lord, I desire to be heard before the Opinion of the Court be given.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: If there be not proof enough to induce the Jury to believe this is their Paper; yet sure there is enough to Read it.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert Sawyer.
sp.p: My Lord, we have not been heard to this yet.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Why is this fit to be suffered?

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Mr. Sol. I am always willing to hear Mr. Finch.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: But I hope your Lordship, and the Court, are not to be Complemented into an unusual thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Pemberton.
sp.p: It is not a Complement, but Right and Justice.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Certainly it is Right and Justice, that there should be some limits put to Men's speaking, that we may know when to have an end.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert Sawyer.
sp.p: Mr. Sollicitor does mistake the right, my Lord, for we desire to be heard to this Point▪ as not having spoke to it yet.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let me make my Objection to your being heard: for I believe you and I have been chid several times, for speaking over and over the same thing.

sp.speaker: Sir R. Sawyer.
sp.p: This that we now offer, i •… not to the same Point, that we have spoken to already.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: We are now speaking to the Reading of the Paper, and you have spoken to it already.

sp.speaker: Sir R. Sawyer.
sp.p: If the Court will please to hear us, we have that to offer against the Reading of that Paper, which has not been offered yet.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Sir Robert Sawyer, I take it, it is in the Breast of the Court •… o he •… when they will, and as much as they will, and whom they will; for if Three or Four have been heard of a side to speak what they will, the Court may very well depend upon the Learning of those Three or Four, that they say what can be said upon the Point, and that's enough; but if Six or Seven desire to be heard over and over to the same thing, certainly the Court may stop at Three or Four, if they will.

sp.speaker: Sir R. Sawyer.
sp.p: This is a new Objection that none of us have been heard to yet.

sp.speaker: Mr. Finch.
sp.p: My Lord, that which I offer is not contrary to the Rules of Law, nor contrary to the Practice of the Court; nor was I going any way to invade that Priviledge which Mr. Sollicitor claims of making Objections, and not receiving an Answer.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What a fine Declamation you have now made! I never claimed any such right; but I oppose your being heard over and over to the same thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, let's come to some Issue in this matter.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: I will hear you; but I would not have you introduce it with a reflection upon the King's Council.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, if you impose that upon him, you stop his Mouth; for some Men cannot speak without reflection.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: On the other side, pray Mr. Sollicitor, give us leave to hear fairly what they have to say; for, I perceive, he cannot offer to speak, but you presently stop his Mouth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Finch.
sp.p: My Lord, that which I was going to say, is another matter than any thing that has been yet offered: We say, that this Paper ought not to be Read▪ for that they are obliged by Law to prove their Information; and consequently, having laid a particular place where the thing was done, in the Information, they ought to prove that this was done in that place. The Evidence that they have given, is of my Lords the Bishops Writing this Paper; and they have laid it to be done in Middlesex: and this, with submission to your Lordship, is local; and they must prove it to be Written in Middlesex, where they have laid it, or else they fail in their proof. This is another Objection, which as yet hath not been spoken to: That if there be a proof of their Hand-writing, yet there is no proof where that Hand was Written; and therefore they are not yet got so far, as to have it Read against my Lords.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: For that Point, my Lord, we say, This would have been as properly said after the Paper had been Read, when they come to make Objections against our Proof, by way of Defence: and with submission, it had been more proper then, than it is now For what are we now doing My Lord, we are Proving that such a Paper was Subscribed by my Lords the Bishops; and Sir Iohn Nicholas gives you an Account, that he had it from his Majesty at the Council and that certainly is in the County of Middlesex; and i •… will concern you to Prove that it was Written elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Pemberton.
sp.p: That's very well Mr. Attorney▪ sure you do not think as you speak.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Here is a Paper Composed and Written by you, that Sir Iohn Nicholas says he had from his Majesty; how he came by it. I suppose you will tell us by and by; this is your Hand-writing, that I think we have proved sufficiently, this is found in the County of Middlesex; and you come and tell us, that we must Prove that it was Written in the County of Middlesex; and it is taken to be Written where it was found, unless you Prove the contrary.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Pemberton.
sp.p: That's pretty Doctrine indeed, and very new.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, here's an Objection made too timely: we are now upon Reading of this Paper: and the Question is, Whether it shall be Read or not be Read. Surely we have given Evidence enough to induce the Court to Read it: and it is another Question, that will come time enough afterwards; Where it was Writen?

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Truly, I do not think it was proper for you to stand upon the Place where it was Written as yet.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Levinz.
sp.p: When we are upon an Information of a Fact in Middlesex, will you hear them give Evidence of a Fact in Yorkshire?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: We are not to be driven by these Gentlemen; we are to be directed by the Court.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: I think truly it is yet too early to make this Objection.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Pemberton.
sp.p: Surely, my Lord, this is our time to oppose the Reading of it, as not proved.

sp.speaker: Mr. I. Powell.
sp.p: Mr. Sollicitor, I think you have not sufficiently proved this Paper to be Subscribed by my Lords the Bishops.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Not to Read it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. I. Powell.
sp.p: No, not to Read it, it is too slender a Proof for such a Case: I grant you, in Civil Actions a slender proof is sufficient, to make out a Man's Hand, by a Letter to a Tradesman, or a Correspondent, or the like; but in Criminal Causes (such as this) if such a proof be allowed, where is the safety of your Life or any Man's Life here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: We tell you a Case where it was allowed; and that is Mr. Sidney's Case; a Case of Treason, and Printed by Authority: We tell you nothing, but what was done to'ther day.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: I tell you what I say to it; I think truly there is proof enough to have it Read: and I am not ashamed nor afraid to say it; for I know I speak with the Law: say what you will of Criminal Cases, and the danger of Peoples Lives; there were more danger to the Government, if such proof were not allowed to be good.

sp.speaker: Mr. I. Powel.
sp.p: I think there is no danger to the Government at all, in requiring good proof against Offenders.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Here's my Lord Archbishop and the Bishop of St. Asaph and my Lord of Ely, their Hands are proved; it is proved to be my Lord Archbishop's Writing by Mr. Brookes, and he proves my Lord of Ely's Hand by Comparison, and so my Lord of St. Asaph's. Now Brother Pemberton, there's an Answer to your Objection; it being proved that it is all my Lord Archbishop's Hand: then they come and say, We'll prove the Hands of the others by comparison: and for that they bring you Witnesses, that say, They have received Letters from them, and seen their Hand-writing several times: and comparing what they have seen with this very Paper; says the Witness, I do believe it to be his Hand. Can there be a greater Evidence or a fuller?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Pemberton.
sp.p: Admit it be a full Evidence against my Lord Arch-Bishop: What's that to the rest? There's no Evidence against them.

sp.speaker: Mr. I. Allybone.
sp.p:
Brother Pemberton, as to the Objection you make of Comparing of Hands; it is an Objection indeed, I do agree: but then consider the inconvenience which you and Mr. Pollixfen do so much insist upon: If a Man should be accused by Comparison of Hands, Where is he? He is in a lamentable Case; for his Hand may be so Counterseited, that he himself may not be able to distinguish it. But then you do not consider where you are on the other side: that may be an Objection in matters of Fact, that will have very little weight, if compared and set altogether. For, on the other side, where shall the Government be, if I will make Libels, and traduce the Government with Prudence and Discretion, and all the secrecy imaginable? I'll Write my Libel by my self, prove it as you can; that's a fatal blot to the Government; and therefore the Case is not the same; nor is your Doctrine to pass for current here; because every Case depends upon its own Fact. If I take upon me to Swear I know your Hand, the inducements are to my self, how I came to know it, so as to Swear it: Knowledge
depends on Circumstances; I swear that I know you, but yet I may be under a mistake, for I can have my knowledge of you no other way but from the visibility of you, and another Man may be so like you, that there is a possibility of my being mistaken; but certainly, that is Evidence, and good Evidence: Now here are several Gentlemen that swear as to my Lord Archbishop's Hand-writing; I do agree, as to some of the others, that the Evidence is not so strong; for what that Man said, that he did believe it was rather such a Lord's Hand, than that which went before, or that which came after, it is of no weight at all, and so some of the others; but it is positively proved against my Lord Archbishop and one or two more; so that that's enough to induce the reading of this writing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iust. Holloway.
sp.p: Good my Lord, let me give my opinion.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: Ay, withall my heart, Brother.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iust. Holloway.
sp.p: My Lord, I think as this Case is, there ought to be a more strong proof, for certainly the proof ought to be stronger and more certain in Criminal matters than in Civil matters; in Civil matters, we do go upon slight proof, such as the comparison of Hands, for proving a Deed, or a Witnesses Name, and a very small proof will induce us to read it; but in Criminal matters we ought to be more strict, and require positive and substantial proof, that is fitting for us to have in such a Case, and without better proof, I think it ought not to be read.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: You must go on to some other proof Mr. Sollicitour, for the Court is divided in their Opinions about this proof.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Then, my Lord, we will come to the Confessions of my Lords the Bishops, and I hope that will be believed by all Man-kind.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Truly my Lord, we did forbear that Evidence, and would not have proceeded this way, if we had had fair play on the other side.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro. Sawyer.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney, give us leave to defend our Clients all the ways we can; I think we doe nothing but what is fair; the Court you see is divided, therefore we did not without reason insist upon it.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: You must go on as you can, for they will put you upon it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mr. Blathwayt.

div.p: Mr. Blathwayt Sworn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Pray hand the writing to him.

div.p: The writing shown to him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Have you seen that writing formerly Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: What did you hear my Lord Arch-Bishop say about that Paper?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: And the rest of my Lords the Bishops.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: First we'll ask as to my Lord Arch-Bishop; did he own it to be his Hand-writing?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: My Lord, I believe this to be the Paper that my Lord Arch-bishop did own to be subscribed by him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: When was it owned by him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: On the Council day, the Eighth of this Month.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Where was it owned, because we would obviate that Objection of the County?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: It was at the Council Table at Whitehall.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: What say you to the Bishop of St. Asaph? Did he own it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: Yes; All my Lords the Bishops did own it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Name them particularly; what say you the Bishop of Ely?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: In the same manner, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: The Bishop of Chichester?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: In the same manner.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: The Bishop of Bath and Wells?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: The Bishop of Peterborough?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: And the Bishop of Bristol?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: So; We have proved they all owned it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iust. Holloway.
sp.p: Could not this have been done at first, and saved all this trouble?

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer.
sp.p: Have you done with Mr. Blathwayt, Mr. Attorney, that we may ask him some questions.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Ask him what you will.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Pemb.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Blathwayt, upon what occasion did they own it, you are Sworn to tell the whole truth; pray tell all your Knowledge, and the whole Confession that they made.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: My Lord, I am called here by a Subpoena to answer on behalf of the King; my Lord, I am ready to doe my duty, and I beg of your Lordship that you would please to tell me what is my duty; for whatsoever I shall answer, I shall speak the truth in.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Pemb.
sp.p: There is nothing desired, but that you would speak the truth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: My Lord, I am easily guided by your Lordship what I ought to answer to.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: What is it you ask him, Brother Pemberton?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Pemb.
sp.p: We desire Mr. Blathwayt to tell the whole discourse that passed at the Council, when he says my Lords the Bishops owned this Paper.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: That's a very pretty thing indeed.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: Look you, Mr. Blathwayt, you must answer them what they ask you, unless it be an ensnaring Question, and that the Court will take care of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: If your Lordship please to ask me any Question, I shall readily answer it.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: You must answer them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Pemb.
sp.p: We ask you upon what occasion they came to own their Hands? What discourse was made to them, and what they answered?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: My Lord, I beg your Lordship's directions.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: Come, tell it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: My Lord, the occasion was this; This Paper was read in Council, and I had the honour to read it before the King, and it having been read before his Grace the Arch-Bishop, and my Lords the Bishops, they were asked whethey did own that Paper, and, my Lord, they did own it.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer.
sp.p: Mr. Blathwayt, was that the first time that my Lords the Bishops came in?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: Sir I was not asked that Question.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: What would you have, Sir Robert Sawyer?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert Sawyer.
sp.p: We would have an account what passed at the Council.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: Would you have all the Discourse betwixt the Council and my Lords the Bishops?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Pemb.
sp.p: All that relates to their Accusation, my Lord, their whole Confession, and what was said to them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you think, Mr. Serjcant, that when we call a Witness, you are at liberty to examine him to every impertinent thing?

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, we desire that they may only ask reasonable and proper Questions.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Pemb.
sp.p: Mr. Sollicitour he is sworn to answer and tell the whole truth, and that's all we ask of him.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer.
sp.p: Sir, I will ask you a plain Question upon your Oath, did not my Lord Arch-Bishop, and the rest of my Lords the Bishops, at first resuse to own it, or to answer whether it were their Hands or not?

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: That is not a fair Question Sir Robert Sawyer; 'tis a leading Question.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Pemb.
sp.p: Then I ask you in short, what did they refuse? I am sure that is a fair Question, for God forbid that any should hinder the King's Evidence from telling truth.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer.
sp.p: And God forbid that half Evidence should condemn any man.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: God forbid the Truth should be concealed any way.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Pemb.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, when they were first asked, whether that was their Hands or not, what answer did they give?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: Sir, I have begged the favour of my Lords the Judges to tell me what I am to answer, and what Questions are proper for me to answer to.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Iust.
sp.p: You must answer any Questions that are not ensnaring Questions.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert Sawyer.
sp.p: Mr. Blathwayt, you are upon your Oath to testifie the Truth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: Sir, I am not acquainted with the Methods of Law, I desire my Lords the Judges would instruct me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iust. Ailibone.
sp.p: Answer to the Question that they ask you.

sp.speaker: Ld. Ch. Iust.
sp.p: We observe what they ask you; we'll take care that they ask you nothing but what they should.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: I desire the Question may be repeated.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: When they were first asked if it were their Hands, what answer did they give the King?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: His Grace the Archbishop, and my Lords the Bishops, at first did not immediately answer whether the Paper were theirs or no.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Peinberton.
sp.p: What did they say?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: They said they did humbly hope, if they were put to answer, no advantage should be taken against them.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: What did they say farther at that time concerning His Majesties pleasure?

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: That's a leading Question, Mr. S. Pemberton, you cannot leave your way of leading Witnesses.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: It is a very strange thing; if we ask a question that's general, that's excepted to; if we ask any question in particular, then they find fault with us, that it is a leading Question; so that we can never ask a question that will please them. Pray Mr. Blathwayt, what did they say concerning the King's pleasure, whether they would answer if the King commanded them?

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Trinder.
sp.p: How can it be material what they said?

sp.speaker: L. Cn. Iust.
sp.p: It is material that it should be asked, and that it should be answered.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Levinz.
sp.p: You are to tell the whole Truth, Sir, Pray tell us what did my Lords the Bishops say about submitting to the King's pleasure?

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: What is that to the purpose?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pollixfen.
sp.p: Mr. Sollicitour, his Oath is to tell the truth, and the whole truth, and therefore he must answer my question.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: You are mighty loth, Mr. Sollicitour, to let us hear the truth; I would not willingly lead him in any thing, and I cannot see that this is any leading question, unless his Oath be against Law, which says he is to tell the whole truth.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, I do beg your Lordship's favour of a word in this thing: It is certain, if they ask any thing that shall take off the Evidence that was first given, that it is not true, I cannot oppose it; but if they ask questions onely to conflame, and to possess people with foolish notions, and strange conceits, that is not to the fact that we are now trying—

sp.speaker: Sr. Rob. Sawyer.
sp.p: 'Tis onely to have the truth out that we doe it.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: There is no body here that will be enflamed, Mr. Attorney; I have asked a fair question, the Court has ruled it so.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: I shall readily answer any question that the Court thinks fit.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: Sir, by the Oath you have taken you are to tell the whole truth.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Iust.
sp.p: Is he to tell you all that was done at the Council board that day?

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: No, my Lord; onely what passed there about my Lords the Bishops Confession, the whole of that matter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: There has been so much said between the asking of the question and this time, that I desire it may be repeated, that I may know what to answer to.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: I ask you in short, Sir, What did my Lords the Bishops say at the time of their appearing in Council concerning the King's pleasure, whether they should answer or not?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p:
The first time my Lords the Bishops came into the Council, they were asked the question whether they did own that Paper; they did immediately answer, They humbly hoped, as they stood there Criminals, His Majesty
would not take advantage against them, but however they would obey His Majesties Command.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer.
sp.p: Were they commanded to withdraw?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: Yes, thereupon they were commanded to withdraw, which they did.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: When they came in again what questions were asked them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: They came in several times, more than twice, I have reason to remark this, that they did so; Do you mean the second time, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: The second time they seemed unwilling to own the Paper.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer.
sp.p: And what did they doe the third time.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: But first let us know what more was done the second time.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo. Treby.
sp.p: How was that unwillingness of theirs overcome?

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: When they exprest their unwillingness what did they say farther?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: If I remember right, they said as they did the first time, they humbly hoped His Majesty would not take advant •… ge against them.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: Then what did they say the third time?

sp.speaker: Sr. Rob. Sawyer.
sp.p: Pray, were they asked whether they published it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: As to the publishing it, it was laid before them, and I think they were asked the question whether they published it?

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer.
sp.p: And what answer did they make?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: I remember His Grace, and my Lords the Bishops, did not own they had published it, but they denied it.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo. Treby.
sp.p: After they discovered their unwillingness the second time, what followed next?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: They did withdraw after the second Attendence.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Levins.
sp.p: But what was said to them? Was that all that was said to them the second time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: I have said two things already, that they were unwilling to answer, and that they denied the publishing.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Iust.
sp.p: This is strange usage of a Witness, to put him to tell every thing that was said.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: I would ask you this question, Sir, When they came in the second time, whether they did desire to know if it were His Majesties Command that they should own it?

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Iust.
sp.p: That I must not permit you to ask, Brother, that is to lead the Witness.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: My Lord, he will not answer general questions; I have asked him all along general questions, and I cannot get an answer from him to them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: I am ready to answer any questions that the Court thinks I should answer; I am not backward to answer according to my duty.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Iust.
sp.p: Let one of you ask a question at a time, and not chop in one upon another.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: In all the Tryalls that ever I have been in, in all the Cases of Criminals, the King's Witnesses used to be treated with respect, and not to be fallen upon in this manner.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Iust.
sp.p: He shall be sure to have all respect paid him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: He is in Office under the King.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: I do not think Mr. Blathwayt does believe I would shew him any disrespect, more than he would shew me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: I beg one word, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Iust.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney, What do you say?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, I say I do oppose the asking of this question, not but that every man has a right to cross examine a Witness, but if they ask such a question, let them tell us what use they would make of it.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Iust.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney General, for that matter—

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: My Lord, if you please I'll give Mr. Attorney an answer.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Iust.
sp.p: Brother Pemberton, I was speaking to Mr. Attorney, and pray hear me, I will not ask you what use you'll make of the question you ask, but do you ask fair and regular questions, and I'll take care you shall have an answer to them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Pemberton.
sp.p: I will deal plainly with the Court, and tell you what use we intend to make of our question; if they answered under a Promise from His Majesty, that it should not be given in Evidence against them, I hope they shall not take advantage of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: I say that is a very unmannerly question, but however it shall be answered.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Pemberton.
sp.p: Why so, Mr. Sollicitour?

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, it is to put something upon the King which I dare hardly name.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: We do not know what Answer will be made to it yet, but it does look like an odd kind of question.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: If men will be so pressing, I, for the King, desire the question may be entred.

sp.speaker: Sir R. Sawyer.
sp.p: What do you mean, Mr. Sollicitour?

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: I know very well what I mean, Sir; I desire the question may be recorded in Court.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Pemberton.
sp.p: Record what you will, I am not afraid of you, Mr. Sollicitour.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Are you afraid of the Law?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Pemberton.
sp.p: No, nor of you neither.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: Pray be quiet, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Blathwayt, answer whether there was any promise made to my Lords the Bishops from the King.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: My Lord, I take the question to be, whether the King was pleased to make my Lords the Bishops any promise of not taking advantage of what answer they made.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: That is the question.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: As that question is stated there was no such made.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: Look you, he tells you there was no such promise made; there is an Answer to your Question, Brother.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Levinz.
sp.p: We made no such question; but the question I would ask is this,—

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: For the satisfaction of the Court repeat what you said just now, Mr. Blathwayt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: I take the question to be, whether the King made any promise to my Lords the Bishops, that no advantage should be taken of what they said, and I say the King made no such promise.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Pemberton.
sp.p: We did not ask you the question, but we only told you what use we would have made of another question.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pollixfen.
sp.p: Mr. Blathwayt, I see you can very well distinguish what questions are to be answered; I ask you in short upon your Oath, When they were first called in, what was said to them, and what was answered by them?

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: Here has been a great deal of wrangling, but this is a fair question, and may reduce us to order again; tell us o •… er again from the beginning what passed when my Noble Lords the Bishops came in the first, second, and third time, when they were examined about this Paper?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: My Lord, I shall comply with your Lordship's Directions, I apprehend I am to answer together concerning the first, second, and third comings in of my Lords the Bishops into the Council. The first time, (as I said before,) my Lords the Bishops were unwilling to own the Paper, and did say they humbly hoped His Majesty would not take advantage against them, but that they were ready to obey his Command. The second time they were called in they did repeat it again, that they hoped His Majesty would not take advantage against them; after that there was mention made of the Paper being published, I remember my Lords the Bishops said they had not published it.—

sp.speaker: Sir R. Sawyer.
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: You have no mind to hear all, I think.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: How do you expect to be answered your questions, if you interrupt them? Go on, Mr. Blathwayt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p:
Sir, I said last, that they having prayed the King that no advantage might be taken against them for what they should say, there was mention made of the Paper its being published, and my Lords the Bishops did say they had
not published it; and His Grace my Lord Archbishop said it was written with his own Hand, and that he had not made use of his Clerk.

sp.speaker: Sir. R. Sawyer.
sp.p: Is that all you can remember that passed at that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: This is the substance of what I remember.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: Was this the third time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: No; that was the second time, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pollixfen.
sp.p: If there be not some order in this Evidence, my Lord, we shall not be able to observe any thing upon it.—Pray what was done afterwards?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: My Lord Chancellour, upon their coming in, did require them to answer whether they did own that Paper or not; my Lords the Bishops did own the Paper.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pollixfen.
sp.p: Do you remember in what words or expressions (as near as you can) they did own it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Is this a practice to be endured?

sp.speaker: Mr. Finch.
sp.p: Why, he may apprehend and take that to be an owning of it which was not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Has not he sworn the manner of it, and almost the very words?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Levinz.
sp.p: We desire nothing of him but that he will tell us what words they said when they owned it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: It was the third time that they came in, that they owned it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Pemberton.
sp.p: Why, what did they say?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: My Lord Chancellour required them to answer, whether they owned the Paper or no.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Pemberton.
sp.p: What did they say then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: As near as I can remember, His Grace and my Lords the Bishops did own the Paper.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Pemberton.
sp.p: What words did they own it in? tell the manner of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: What's this to the purpose?

sp.speaker: Mr. Finch.
sp.p: Mr. Blathwayt, Did you take notes of what passed there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: I answer, Sir, I did not take notes, for I attended the King at his Elbow, and did not take notes; Mr. Finch, you know the manner of the Council in such cases very well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then we ask you for the King, because they shall not enflame People by such an expression, In what words did they own it, if you can remember?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: Sir, I have declared my memory as well as I can; when the other Clerks come to be examined, if they can tell any more, let them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: But we will have no Discourse to enflame the World; Did the King promise or declare that no advantage should be taken of their confession?

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Iust.
sp.p: I would ask him that question, What was the manner that my Lord Chancellour exprest himself in to them, when they came in the third time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: Assoon as my Lord Chancellour had required them to declare whether they owned that Paper, as well as I remember, His Grace took the Paper in his hand, and it was handed over, or shewed, to my Lords the Holding it forth to the Court. Bishops, and they owned and declared so, just as if they should lay it before the Court, just so: I do not recollect my self of all the circumstances that passed, I only can tell you the substance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: He does not remember what they said particularly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Sollicitour, I know well enough what they mean by the question; I know they would fain possess the World with a belief that there was such a promise made them, and yet they are prosecuted notwithstanding that promise; therefore I do ask you, Mr. Blaithwayt, and for the King's Honour I must ask it, Did the King make any Promise or Declaration, that no advantage should be taken, or use made of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: The King did not make any Promise or Declaration that no advantage should be taken, or use made of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: He only put them upon it, whether they did own it or not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: I ask you upon your Oath, Did my Lord Archbishop own it to be his Head-writing?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: Yes he did, and said he writ it with his own Hand, and would not let his Clerk write it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did he own the whole to be his Hand-writing, or not?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: Yes, he did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did every one of the Bishops own their names subscribed to it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blathwayt.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Then, my Lord, we pray now that it may be read.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: I suppose now they will be content it should be read.

sp.speaker: Mr. Finch.
sp.p: If your Lordship please to favour me one word, I think it cannot yet be read, and my Objection is this:—

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: I thought you had made all your Objections before, as to the reading of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Finch.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, spare us: Here are two parts of this Information; the one is for consulting and conspiring to diminish the King's Royal Prerogative, and for that end they did make and write a seditious Libell; the other part is, that they did publish this seditious Libell: We are hitherto upon the first part, the making and writing of it; both parts are local; untill they have proved the making and writing of it to have been in Middlesex, it is not Evidence upon this Information.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: We have proved it written and published in Middlesex.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Pemb.
sp.p: The contrivance and writing of a Libell is in itself penal, and they may be punished for it, if they be found guilty: Now if they could give an undeniable Evidence concerning the publishing of it, that is nothing to this point; but if they should not give such Evidence, or any Evidence at all of the publication, yet if it be proved that it was written and contrived by them, they would be guilty for so much, if it be a Libell, and this we say is local as well as all the rest; and therefore we insist upon it, that the writing and contriving must as well be proved to be in Middlesex, as the publication, for all is local.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: There is no publishing yet proved.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Levinz.
sp.p: It is true, my Lord, here is nothing of a Publication yet, (with your Lordship's favour,) for their Answer to His Majesty in Council was, that they did not publish it; all that is said yet, is, that they owned the Paper to be their hands: My Lord, does the owning of that own that it was written in the County of Middlesex? or that it was contrived or made there? No surely, upon this Evidence the place is clearly at large: My Lord, this might have been done in the County of Surrey, or Somerset, or any other County: Their Information is, that they did consult and contrive to diminish the King's Prerogative at Westminster in the County of Middlesex, and there they did write, and cause to be written, this Libell, and there they did publish it; suppose it should be granted that it is proved that this is the Archbishop's Hand-writing, and these are their Names to it, is there any one Evidence that any thing of this was done in Middlesex? and, my Lord, that is the thing they are to prove.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sommers.
sp.p: If your Lordship please, all matters of Crime are so local, that if it be not proved to be done in the County where it is laid, the party accused is as innocent, as if he never had done the thing; and, with submission, it is the very point of the Information; that it be proved they are guilty of the Fact in the place where it is laid to be done.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: This is the same thing over and over again; but I am content to hear you, Mr. Sommers, at any time; I have told you my opinion about reading of the Paper already, if you'll have it again you may.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pollixfen.
sp.p: Pray, good my Lord, spare us, before it be read.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iust. Holloway.
sp.p: Mr. Pollixfen, you have not yet had the Directions of the Court for the reading of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, when this Paper is read, which we pray it may be, we will answer their Objections, but at present we say, they are out of time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pollixfen.
sp.p: Good Lord, what a •… ange thing is this! We object against the reading of it, and you'll answer us after it is read.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Certainly, my Lord, we have done enough to prove that this is a paper owned by them in the County of Middlesex, and we pray it may be read.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Iust.
sp.p: Truly I am of the same mind I was before, that it is too soon to make the Objection, and that the Paper ought to be read.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: We submit to your Rule.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pollixfen.
sp.p: If it be the Will of the Court, I have nothing to say.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iust. Powell.
sp.p: My Lord, The Contrivance and Publication are both matters of Fact, and upon Issue joined the Jurors are Judges of the Fact, as it is laid in the Information; but how can they be Judges of a matter of Fact done in another County? and it must be presumed, in favour of Innocence, not to be done in this County, but in another, except they prove it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We are not yet ripe for arguing that point.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: We are speaking only to the Court now for the reading of this Paper, and the Jury are not Judges of that, whether the Paper ought to be read or no; that is merely a matter of Law, and under the direction of the Court; and therefore I pray, since it is now in your Lordship's Judgment, whether that Paper should be read, that you would please to order it to be read.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: I can only give you my own opinion, let my Brothers give theirs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iust. Holloway.
sp.p: There is no body against the reading of it, my Lord; I suppose my Brother Powell is not against its being read.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iust. Powell.
sp.p: But they say the King's Counsel must make it out first, that the writing of it, and the conspiring about it was in the County of Midds. or there can be no judgment, so much as to read it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pollixfen.
sp.p: My Lord, If the Objection be saved to us, we shall not so much oppose the reading it, only we would not be surprized in point of time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iust. Powell.
sp.p: Nay, if they consent to the reading, we have no reason to hinder it.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: Brother, I believe they know well enough what they have to say for their Clients; let the Paper be read.

sp.speaker: Clerk reads:
sp.p: The Humble Petition of William Archbishop of Canterbury—

sp.speaker: Sir. R. Sawyer.
sp.p: Read the whole Petition; Pray, my Lord, that the whole may read. Read the Top first, Sir; to whom it was directed.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: Read the whole.

sp.speaker: Clerk reads:
sp.p: To the King's Most Excellent Majesty.

The Humble Petition of William Archbishop of Canterbury, and of divers of the Suffragan Bishops of that Province, now present with him, in behalf of themselves and others of their absent Brethren, and of the Clergy of their respective Dioceses,

THat the great aversness they find in themselves to the distributing and publishing in all their Churches your Majesties late Declaration for Liberty of Conscience, proceedeth neither from any want of Duty and Obedience to your Majesty, (our holy Mother, the Church of England, being both in her Principles and in her constant practice unquestionably loyal; and having (to her great Honour) been more than once publickly acknowledged to be so by your Gratious Majesty,) nor yet from any want of due tenderness to Dissenters, in relation to whom they are willing to come to such a Temper as shall be thought fit, when that matter shall be considered and settled in Parliament and Convocation; but amongst many other considerations, from this especially, because that Declaration is founded upon such a Dispencing Power, as hath been often declared illegal in Parliament, and particularly in the Years 1662, and 1672, and in the beginning of your Majesties Reign; and is a matter of so great moment and consequence to the whole Nation, both in Church and State, that your Petitioners cannot in Prudence, Honour, or Conscience, so far make themselves parties to it, as the Distribution of it all over the Nation, and the solemn Publication of it once and again, even in God's House, and in the time of his Divine Service, must amount to, in common and reasonable Construction:
Your Petitioners therefore most humbly and earnestly beseech your Majesty, that You will be gratiously pleased not to insist upon their Distributing and Reading your Majesties said Declaration:
And Your Petitioners (as in duty bound) shall ever pray, &c.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, we shall leave our Evidence here, and hear what they can object to it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Finch.
sp.p: Have you no farther Evidence, Mr. Attorney?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We leave it here for the present.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: The Gentlemen of the Jury desire to see the Petition.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Iust.
sp.p: Shew it them.

div.p: (The Petition was shewn to the Iury.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Finch.
sp.p: But will you give no farther Evidence, Mr. Attorney?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: I tell you we'll leave it here, till we see what you say to it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Finch.
sp.p: There is nothing that we should say any thing to.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Make your Advantage of it; if it be nothing, we can have nothing.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: What say you for the Defendents, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mr. Finch.
sp.p: My Lord, in short, we say that hitherto they have totally failed, for they have not proved any Fact done by us in Middlesex, nor have they proved any Publication at all.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert Sawyer.
sp.p: They have given no Evidence of any thing.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: Pray Gentlemen speak One at once, and then we shall understand the better what we hear.

sp.speaker: Sir R. Sawyer.
sp.p: My Lord, We say, they have given no Evidence of the Conspiring, Writing, or Pulibshing in Middlesex; Nay, as to the Publication, there is none at all proved.

sp.speaker: Mr. Finch.
sp.p: Here is no proof of any Publication, nor of the writing or making in Middlesex; so that there is no proof at all against my Lords, the Bishops.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: You heard what Mr. Blathwayt said, they owned it in Middlesex.

sp.speaker: Mr. Finch.
sp.p: That is not a Publication sure, or any Evidence where it was done.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Levinz,
sp.p: Suppose, my Lord, that I own in Middlesex, that I robb'd a man in Yorkshire, will that make me guilty in Middlesex?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: But if you had stole a Horse in Yorkshire, and had that Horse in Middlesex, and owned it, I doubt it would go hard with you in Middlesex?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Serjeant thinks he has put a very home Comparison, but we shall shew how little significant it is by and by.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Levinz.
sp.p: My Lord, in the first place we insist upon it; here is no proof in this Case at all, as to the doing of any Fact at all in the County of Middlesex; In the next place, this Information and Petition do not agree; for they have brought an Information, and set forth, That my Lords the Bishops under pretence of a Petition did make a Libel, and they have set forth no Petition at all, all the Petitionary part is omitted: If I will take part of a man's words, and not the whole, and make a Libel of that part, certainly that is very disingenuous and injurious; For that part that I omit may alter the Sense of the whole. They here ought to set forth the Petition, with the Direction to the King, and the Prayer at the end, whereby it will appear what the whole is, and what was desired by their Petition. But, my Lord, to make this matter a little more clear, whatsoever they say of its being my Lord Archbishop's Hand, we shall prove that if it were so, it could not be done in Middlesex; for we shall prove that my Lord of Canterbury had not been in Middlesex for three or four Months before.

sp.speaker: Sir Robere Sawyer.
sp.p: Pray let the Information be read, then you will the see variance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: There is not the latter part (we acknowledge) in the Information.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: There may be, and is, a sic Continetur, and there is no Objection in that at all.

sp.speaker: L. C. Iust.
sp.p: It is sic Continetur, and that's———

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer.
sp.p: The truth of it is, this Information has made a very deformed thing of it, has left it neither Head nor Tail; they style it a Petition, but it is without any Direction to any body, and without any Prayer for any thing; and without those two it cannot be told what it is.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iust. Allybone.
sp.p: Sir Rob. Sawyer, if I mistake not, it is said only under pretence of a Petition.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer.
sp.p: There may be more in the Paper, than in the Information, and if all were in, one part might explain another.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p:
So there may be more; and I wonder to hear that Objection from
Sir Robert Sawyer, who has exhibited so many Informations for Libells in pi •… es taken out of Books.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: All that we alledge in the Information is contained in the Paper, and that's enough for our purpose; we are not bound to recite the whole.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Iust.
sp.p: Indeed I think it is no material Objection at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Pemberton.
sp.p: Truly I think it is very material in this Case; here's a Petition that is preferred to his Majesty; take the whole Petition together, and, say they, it is a reasonable Petition; chop off the Direction and the Prayer, and then here's nothing but the body of a Petition, without beginning or ending; or if a man will say any thing concerning the King, and doe it by way of Petition to himself, that will alter the Case mightily, from a Paper spread about, that should contain only the body of a Petition, and nothing else.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer.
sp.p: Pray read that part of the Information.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pollixfen.
sp.p: If so be there be an Information, and that Information charges a man with a pretended Petition, and the Evidence comes and proves a Petition both top and bottom, that is not the Petition in the Information; for that lacking the proper parts of a Petition, is called a pretended Petition, but that which is proved, is a real one.

sp.speaker: Serj. Baldock.
sp.p: My Lord, there is nothing in this Objection, as this Record hath it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, give us leave to state it on our side, as they have done on theirs, and it will be the better understood upon the reading: I hope it is not come to that pass that they would have it, sure these Gentlemen have not forgot altogether the practice that has been so frequent in this Court; if there be an Information for a Libell, Is there any thing more frequent, than only to recite the material part? Sure they may say in such a Libell is contained so and so, without setting forth the whole Book.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: How many Tryalls have we had here, wherein there has been only a Clause taken out of a Book; as particularly, Baxter's Bible, and Iohnson's Book, and all by virtue of a sic continetur.

sp.speaker: Mr. Finch.
sp.p: That comes not up to our Objection here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iust. Powell.
sp.p: Let us hear the Record read, and then we can judge of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer.
sp.p: We pray, Sir, the Information may be read.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We are here upon all Occasions chopp'd in upon, and I do not know how they come to take this Liberty; I am sure other people had it not in former times, when these Gentlemen stood where we do; as soon as ever we offer to speak, presently there are two or three upon us.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Iust.
sp.p: Let me hear them, Mr. Attorney, make their Objection, and let the Record be read, and that will answer that Objection.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, as for that other thing, they come and tell us, we have set forth a Petition, we say no such thing; in the Information we say, you composed a certain Libell, pretens •… Petitionis, in which are contained such and such things; and now I pray let it be read.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p:
Pray, my Lord, hear me a little first; Take the Information as we have laid it, and I believe there are twenty Presidents that I could give you in an instant of late days practice; so was the Information against Mr. Baxter, so was the Information against Mr. Iohnson, so was the Information against Doctor Eades, and so was the Information against Sir Samuel Barnardiston: They are all in this form, sic continetur; so that as for that matter, we are well enough.
